faqs.question: Ist die Costa Blanca ein guter Ort zum Immobilienkauf?
faqs.answer: Yes, absolutely. Costa Blanca demonstrates consistent 8% year-on-year appreciation, exceptional rental yields (€800+ weekly for 3-bedroom properties), and established infrastructure supporting both permanent residence and investment strategies. The region attracts over 400,000 international residents, indicating sustained demand and community viability.

faqs.question: Können Ausländer Immobilien in Spanien kaufen?
faqs.answer: Yes, non-Spanish citizens can purchase property in Spain without restrictions. UK, EU, and international buyers require a Spanish tax identification number (NIE) and typically engage Spanish notaries to formalize purchases. Legal processes are straightforward, with English-speaking solicitors readily available throughout Costa Blanca.

faqs.question: Welche Kosten fallen beim Immobilienkauf in Spanien an?
faqs.answer: Purchase costs typically total 8-12% of property value: notary fees (0.5-1%), property registration (0.5-1%), legal fees (1-2%), and transfer tax—approximately 8% in the Valencian Community. Some regions offer reduced rates for EU citizens, and first-time buyers may access tax benefits.

faqs.question: Wie hoch sind die Grundsteuern in Spanien?
faqs.answer: Die jährlichen Grundsteuern (IBI) average 0.4-0.6% of cadastral value (typically below market value), costing €150-€300 yearly for properties at this price point. Non-resident property owners pay additional non-resident income tax on imputed rental value (approximately 19-24% of estimated rent), though Spain-EU tax treaties often reduce this burden.

faqs.question: Kann ich als Ausländer eine Hypothek in Spanien bekommen?
faqs.answer: Yes, foreign buyers regularly obtain Spanish mortgages. Most lenders finance 70-80% of property value, requiring 20-30% down payment. Interest rates remain competitive (2.5-4% typically). UK and EU citizens face no restrictions; additional documentation is required for non-EU buyers, but financing remains accessible.

faqs.question: Wie hoch sind die Lebenshaltungskosten an der Costa Blanca?
faqs.answer: Cost of living is substantially lower than Northern Europe—approximately 30-40% less than UK equivalents. Monthly expenses for comfortable living range €1,500-€2,500, including accommodation utilities, food, dining, healthcare, and recreational activities. Utility costs are minimal; food prices are competitive; dining remains affordable even at quality establishments.

faqs.question: Ist die Costa Blanca gut für Rentner?
faqs.answer: Excellent. Over 400,000 retirees reside on Costa Blanca, attracted by climate (320+ sunshine days annually), affordable healthcare, established English-speaking communities, and vibrant social calendars. Healthcare quality matches Northern European standards at a fraction of costs. Pension income stretches considerably further; no mandatory retirement age restrictions exist.

faqs.question: Wie ist das Wetter an der Costa Blanca?
faqs.answer: Exceptional year-round: 320+ sunshine days, average temperatures 12-28°C depending on season. Summers are warm (25-32°C) with low rainfall; winters remain mild (8-17°C). Spring and autumn provide perfect conditions for outdoor activities. Mediterranean microclimate means coastal breezes moderate extreme temperatures—significantly more comfortable than inland Spain.

faqs.question: What are the rental prospects for this property?
faqs.answer: Substantial. Comparable 3-bedroom villas in Finestrat generate €700-€900 weekly during peak season (May-September), yielding €30,000-€40,000 annually with professional management. Off-season lettings and long-term rentals provide year-round income options. International property management companies specializing in Costa Blanca readily handle all logistics.
